trans-unit.source: Provides higher-level services (static methods) for the common XAML tasks of reading XAML and writing an object graph; or reading an object graph and writing XAML file output for serialization purposes.
The modes of the XamlServices class that are used in the most common XAML reading and writing scenarios rely on creating instances of XAML readers and XAML writers.

These readers and writers are specialized but internal implementations of public classes, such as <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader>, <xref:System.Xaml.XamlXmlReader>, and <xref:System.Xaml.XamlObjectWriter>.
To use XamlServices for most scenarios, you can rely on the default internal implementations to obtain the results that you want.
For more specialized scenarios, you might define readers and writers yourself, and then pass them as arguments for overloads of the XamlServices methods.
> [!IMPORTANT] > XamlServices is not the recommended XAML reading or XAML writing API set if you are processing WPF-defined types, or types based on WPF.

For [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] usage, use <xref:System.Windows.Markup.XamlReader?displayProperty=fullName> for reading or loading XAML (or BAML); and <xref:System.Windows.Markup.XamlWriter?displayProperty=fullName> for writing back XAML.

These classes use .NET Framework XAML Services APIs and the XAML readers and XAML writers internally in their implementation; however, they also provide support and specialized XAML schema context for WPF-specific concepts, such as optimizations for dependency properties and WPF known types.
Loads a <xref:System.IO.Stream> source for a XAML reader and writes its output as an object graph.
Different signatures for the Load method specify different types of input for the source XAML.

The Load internal implementation first creates an <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader> by calling <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader.Create%28System.IO.Stream%29> and then creates a new instance of a specialized <xref:System.Xaml.XamlReader> that processes the input.
In order for the Load call to successfully create an object graph, the following must be true: - The source is well-formed and valid XML.
- The source is valid XAML at the language level.
- The XAML types that are specified in the source XAML must resolve to backing types in the relevant XAML namespaces.

For example, XAML types for WPF namespaces can resolve to a WPF XAML namespace as specified in the XAML; the assemblies for WPF must be included in the project or available in the run time; and so on.

> [!IMPORTANT] > <xref:System.Xaml.XamlServices> is not the recommended XAML reading or XAML writing API set if you are processing [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] types, or types based on [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)].

For [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] usage, use <xref:System.Windows.Markup.XamlReader?displayProperty=fullName> for reading or loading XAML; and <xref:System.Windows.Markup.XamlWriter?displayProperty=fullName> for writing back XAML.

These classes use <xref:System.Xaml> APIs internally in their implementation; however, they also provide support for WPF-specific concepts that influence the nature of XAML reading and writing, such as optimizations for dependency properties.
The stream to load as input.
The object graph that is written as output.
stream is .
Creates a XAML reader from a <xref:System.IO.TextReader>, and returns an object graph.
In order to return the object graph, the `textReader` input should be constructed by using its relevant input.
For example, it should pass a <xref:System.IO.StringReader> that is constructed by using a valid XAML-as-string input for the <xref:System.IO.StringReader.%23ctor%28System.String%29> constructor.
The <xref:System.IO.TextReader> to use as the basis for the created <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader>.
The object graph that is returned.
textReader is .
Loads a <xref:System.IO.Stream> source for a XAML reader and returns an object graph.
Different signatures for the Load method specify different types of input for the source XAML.

The Load internal implementation first creates an <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader> by calling <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader.Create%28System.String%29> and then creates a new instance of a specialized <xref:System.Xaml.XamlReader> that processes the input.
In order for the Load call to successfully create an object graph, the following must be true: - The source is well-formed and valid XML.
- The source is valid XAML at the language level.
- The XAML types that are specified in the source XAML must resolve to backing types in the relevant XAML namespaces.

For example, XAML types for WPF namespaces can resolve to a WPF XAML namespace as specified in the XAML; the assemblies for WPF must be included in the project or be available in the run time; and so on.
The file name to load and use as source.
The object graph that is returned.
fileName input is .
Loads a specific XAML reader implementation and returns an object graph.
You should typically use this signature only in the following cases: - You defined your own implementation of a <xref:System.Xaml.XamlReader>.
- You specified settings for a <xref:System.Xaml.XamlReader> that differ from the default settings.
The XAML reader implementation to use as the reader for this <xref uid="langword_csharp_Load" name="Load" href=""></xref> operation.
The object graph that is returned.
xamlReader input is .
Loads a specific XML reader implementation and returns an object graph.
You should typically use this signature only if you defined your own implementation of a <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader>.
The <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader> implementation to use as the reader for this <xref uid="langword_csharp_Load" name="Load" href=""></xref> operation.
The output object graph.
xamlReader input is .
Reads XAML as string output and returns an object graph.
In order for the Parse call to successfully create an object tree, the following must be true: - The `xaml` input is well-formed and valid XML.
- The `xaml` input is valid XAML at the language level.
- The XAML types that are specified in the `xaml` input must resolve to backing types in the relevant XAML namespaces.

For example, XAML types for a WPF namespace can resolve to a WPF XAML namespace as specified in the XAML; the assemblies for WPF must be included in the project or be available in the run time; and so on.

> [!IMPORTANT] > <xref:System.Xaml.XamlServices> is not the recommended XAML reading or XAML writing API set if you are processing [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] types, or types based on [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)].

For [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] usage, use <xref:System.Windows.Markup.XamlReader?displayProperty=fullName> for reading or loading XAML, and <xref:System.Windows.Markup.XamlWriter?displayProperty=fullName> for writing back XAML.

These classes use <xref:System.Xaml> APIs internally in their implementation; however, they also provide support for WPF-specific concepts that influence the nature of XAML reading and writing, such as optimizations for dependency properties.
The XAML string input to parse.
The object graph that is returned.
xaml input is .
Processes a provided object tree into a XAML node representation, and returns a string representation of the output XAML.
The output from this method is the `ToString` result of an <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriter> that is created by the method call.

That <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriter> is created by using the following settings: <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriterSettings.Indent%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is `true`; and <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriterSettings.OmitXmlDeclaration%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is `true`.

The returned string can be loaded as valid XML through the <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader.Create%2A> method if you processed the string into a stream, or into a reader more specifically dedicated for XAML.
The root of the object graph to process.
The XAML markup output as a string.
Processes a provided object graph into a XAML node representation and then into an output stream for serialization.
The destination stream.
The root of the object graph to process.
stream input is .
Processes a provided object graph into a XAML node representation and then into an output that goes to the provided <xref:System.IO.TextWriter>.
The <xref:System.IO.TextWriter> that writes the output.
The root of the object graph to process.
writer input is .
Processes a provided object graph into a XAML node representation and then writes it to an output file at a provided location.

The `fileName` parameter value is used as the `outputFileName` input for a call to <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriter.Create%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, which creates a <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriter> as part of the method call.
The name and location of the file to write the output to.
The root of the object graph to process.
fileName is an empty string.
fileName is .
Processes a provided object graph into a XAML node representation and then writes it to the provided XAML writer.
You should typically use this signature only in the following cases: - You defined your own implementation of a <xref:System.Xaml.XamlWriter>.
- You specified settings for the <xref:System.Xaml.XamlWriter> that differ from the default settings.
The <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlWriter"></xref> implementation to use.
The root of the object graph to process.
writer input is .
Processes a provided object graph into a XAML node representation and then writes it to the provided <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriter>.
The <xref:System.Xml.XmlWriter> implementation to use.
The root of the object graph to process.
writer input is .
Connects a <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlReader"></xref> and a <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlWriter"></xref> to use a common XAML node set intermediary.
Potentially transforms the content, depending on the types of readers and writers that are provided.
This method is a wrapper around <xref:System.Xaml.XamlServices.Transform%28System.Xaml.XamlReader%2CSystem.Xaml.XamlWriter%2CSystem.Boolean%29>, where `closeWriter` is specified as `true`.
The <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlReader"></xref> implementation to use.
The <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlWriter"></xref> to use.
xamlReader or xamlWriter input is .
The XAML schema context does not match between the provided xamlReader and xamlWriter.
Connects a <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlReader"></xref> and a <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlWriter"></xref> to use a common XAML node set intermediary.
Potentially transforms the content, depending on the types of readers and writers that are provided.
Provides a parameter for specifying whether to close the writer after the call is completed.
The <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlReader"></xref> implementation to use.
The <xref href="System.Xaml.XamlWriter"></xref> to use.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> to close the writer after the call is complete; <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> to leave the writer active at the last written position.
xamlReader or xamlWriter input is .
The XAML schema context does not match between the provided xamlReader and xamlWriter.
